title: If my spouse files bankruptsy and we have separate credit will ny creditors close my separate accounts
question: my husband is filing bankruptsy and i was told that it would be reported on my credit that he is filing but that i am not and there is a chance that my creditors my decide to close my accounts even of my payments have been on time. i was encouraged to file with him. we lost our home even with being in escrow the bank sold it we got a letter days later from the bank telling us that there was a buyer and to contact them. our agent called and theysaid they were very sorry but the auction side and the escrow side dont always communucate with each other..most of the debt on my husbands cards were used to keep up with the mortgage until hhe sold the home but it never happened.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy means test,Joint accounts during bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Deficiency balance,Bankruptcy and debt,Foreclosure,Spousal debt,Marriage,General Practice
answers:
If you have a deficiency balance from the foreclosure, you might want to consider filing. If you do not, you will not be included in your husband's bankruptcy at all. Your name will not appear on the petition either. Your income, to the extent that it is contributed to the household, will be included in the petition. All of your income will be included on the means test, but money that you pay toward expenses that are not household expenses can be excluded through the marital deduction.

If you do not file, your debts will not be listed and they will not be closed. They can be closed if you fall behind. Credit limits can be cut if your credit drops. You may want to pull your credit reports through 877-FACT-ACT and review them. The bankruptcy should not appear on your report. However, if you have joint accounts, the tag lines may reveal that those accounts are involved in bankruptcy. However, the report should never state that you are involved in bankruptcy unless you actually file.

If your husband is a co-signor on any of the credit cards they will be closed.

I guess my question would be why would you not want to file with your husband? If you already lost your house for non-payment then your credit has already take a terrible hit. Why not take clear your entire credit record at this time and give your self a fresh start? As far as your separate accounts being closed I don't think they will be shut off if they are not listed, and they are not attached to your husbands credit. You will be listed on his bankruptcy along with your associated income since he is married. Take the time to pull your credit reports for you and your husband and make sure that the debt is not listed on both.
